title: Censoring drill artists is an attack on Black self-expression
text:
Rico Racks was jailed for three years for drug offences and also told by the judge that he is banned from rapping specific slang words (Picture: Rico Racks in his video Sinning and Winning/YouTube)

You might have thought that the end of Form 696 would be the end of UK police targeting Black musicians. But in the two years since it was scrapped, a number of drill artists have been censored by police.

Form 696 was a form that promoters and venues had to submit to the Metropolitan Police two weeks before an event, supplying them with information such as the names and phone numbers of DJs and artists, and most worryingly of all, the genre of music being performed, and the target ethnic group.

The form was used to racially discriminate against Black artists, with many grime, garage, and drum’n’bass raves in particular being shut down in the 2000s and 2010s. Police would strong arm venues into cancelling events, often at the very last minute.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The form was scrapped after a review by Mayor Sadiq Khan in November 2017 – but as we can see now, that hasn’t stopped the police from censoring Black music.

Drill artists Skengdo x AM earlier this year received an injunction prohibiting them from performing certain songs live. More recently, rapper Rico Racks was jailed for three years for drug offences and also told by the judge that he is banned from rapping specific slang words.

Banning the use of words such as ‘trapping’ (drug dealing), ‘bandoe’ (a drug house), ‘connect’ (a drugs contact) and ‘whip’ (car) is an extreme counter-measure. The injunction doesn’t even specify the context in which the words can’t be used. It’s an outright encroachment on Rico Racks’ freedom of speech.

Judges have deemed that the use of these words incites violence, but really, it’s about the perceived threat of Blackness, and music being a form of self-expression and liberty.

By censoring the speech of marginalised people, you remove the liberating power of telling their stories.

The pressure shouldn’t have to be on young Black people having to code their language even further, particularly in live music settings, just to avoid police harassment.

Just as Form 696 was used to censor grime in the past, drill music is now in the hot seat and being targeted by the authorities. Police are using similar tactics as they used to use to get grime shows and events cancelled. Skengdo x AM, who received their injunction in January, recently told TRENCH Magazine that the police had previously also contacted venues in attempts to get their shows cancelled.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Music led by Black youth has always been considered ‘rebel music’, as coined by dub poet Linton Kwesi Johnson. In the 00s, grime presented a new challenge for the establishment: it was much darker and bass-led in tone and energy, compared to the reggae that came decades before it.

It wasn’t the music alone that was seen as a threat – if a grime rave was held by white people in Mayfair, there likely wouldn’t be an issue. It’s the idea that the presence of young Black people in groups, mainly men, is seen as a threat to public safety.

In times of austerity, drill (like grime before it) has become a viable path to earning a livelihood for a lot of artists and MCs. With youth violence being considered an urgent social issue, removing one of the few outlets young Black people have to not only make a living, but also to express themselves, will only further alienate and disenfranchise them.

Drill as a genre is on-the-nose and graphic, as artists express the realities of poverty they’ve had to face. Shows like Top Boy depict this life, but drill gets right to the heart of it, because the stories being shared are from those who are voiceless.

The pressure shouldn’t have to be on young Black people having to code their language even further, particularly in live music settings, just to avoid police harassment.

Advertisement

Further criminalisation hasn’t solved crime, and using artists to set an example sets a dangerous precedent. We need to continue to fight to protect self-expression in Black art if we are to avoid history repeating itself.
